qas.question: Avant-garde atonal compositions were written for what instrument?
What two characteristics of classical music can not be attributed to other genres?

answers.text: use of a printed score and the performance of very complex instrumental works

qas.question: Through what period did the symphony not exist?
What has become a defining feature of classical music?
What did not exist through the entire classical music period?
The use of a printed score and the performance of very complex instrumental works are characteristics of what?

context: Given the wide range of styles in classical music, from Medieval plainchant sung by <a0_0><a7_0>monks<a7_0/><a0_0/> to Classical and Romantic symphonies for orchestra from the 1700s and 1800s to avant-garde atonal compositions for <a1_0>solo piano<a1_0/> from the 1900s, it is difficult to list characteristics that can be attributed to all works of that type. However, there are characteristics that <a6_0>classical music<a6_0/> contains that few or no other genres of music contain, such as the <a2_0>use of a printed score and the performance of very complex instrumental works<a2_0/> (e.g., the fugue). As well, although <a5_0>the symphony<a5_0/> did not exist through <a3_0>the entire classical music period<a3_0/>, from the mid-1700s to the 2000s <a4_0>the symphony ensemble<a4_0/>—and the works written for it—have become a defining feature of classical music.
